Article.ArticleTitle: US COVID-19 Shutdown Demonstrates Importance of Background NO<sub>2</sub> in Inferring NO<sub>x</sub> Emissions From Satellite NO<sub>2</sub> Observations.

AbstractText: Satellite nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) measurements are used extensively to infer nitrogen oxide emissions and their trends, but interpretation can be complicated by background contributions to the NO<sub>2</sub> column sensed from space. We use the step decrease of US anthropogenic emissions from the COVID-19 shutdown to compare the responses of NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations observed at surface network sites and from satellites (Ozone Monitoring Instrument [OMI], Tropospheric Ozone Monitoring Instrument [TROPOMI]). After correcting for differences in meteorology, surface NO<sub>2</sub> measurements for 2020 show decreases of 20% in March-April and 10% in May-August compared to 2019. The satellites show much weaker responses in March-June and no decrease in July-August, consistent with a large background contribution to the NO<sub>2</sub> column. Inspection of the long-term OMI trend over remote US regions shows a rising summertime NO<sub>2</sub> background from 2010 to 2019 potentially attributable to wildfires.
